scopecontent.p: The Union Fire Company, Philadelphia's first volunteer fire-fighting organization, was founded in 1736 by Benjamin Franklin and 24 other leading citizens. It was dissolved in 1843. The minutes, 1736-1843 (2 volumes), are primarily concerned with financial matters and the maintenance of equipment. There are also ledgers of members' accounts, 1797-1829 (2 volumes), and miscellaneous papers relating to the Company's land interests.
